quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Uber always has this mentality and Opendoor does two of the product operations, twin turbine jet plane where you can fly the plane on one engine for a little bit if you need to, but it's operating most efficiently and effectively if both are working together.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why product and operations must run in tandem to scale effectively.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Gave a really deep understanding of how the business actually works. It's a pretty good foundation for them going on to say, okay, what do we actually want to build in a more scalable technology way.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on how ops experience grounds product decisions in real business mechanics and scalability needs.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I've slept on the floor in China before launching uberPOOL, and when you reflect the stress onto your teams, everybody tenses out. It counterintuitively doesn't produce better outcomes.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A concrete example plus a counterintuitive leadership lesson: projecting stress harms team performance rather than improving it.

quotes.topic_title: How ops experience shapes product leadership
quotes.text: Starting on the operations side gave a really deep understanding of how the business actually works.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Highlights ops as a fast path to building business intuition that improves product decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: How ops experience shapes product leadership
quotes.text: You are truly operating it day in and day out and the success of the city is in large part driven by the inputs that you are putting into it every single day on the ground and whether or not there was rain that weekend, which was a nice driver of metrics,
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Shows how ops exposes real-world drivers (including external factors) that shape metrics and priorities.

quotes.topic_title: How ops experience shapes product leadership
quotes.text: but talking to customers every single day like one-on-one onboarding drivers responding to support tickets, there's no centralized support team, there was no closer to the customer, right?
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Emphasizes direct, daily customer contact as a powerful input for product judgment.

quotes.topic_title: How ops experience shapes product leadership
quotes.text: And so I think that foundation actually for really understanding what moves the business and being super close to the customer actually is a pretty good foundation for them going on to say, okay, what do we actually want to build in a more scalable technology way?
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Connects ops learnings to a scalable product-building mindset: learn the levers first, then automate with tech.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Tired of bouncing around multiple tools to uncover what's really happening inside your product?
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights the practical pain of fragmented tooling and the value of consolidating product insight workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: First, Pendo is built around product analytics, seeing what your users are actually doing in your apps so that you can optimize their experience.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Emphasizes behavior-based analytics as the foundation for improving product experience.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And the new thing in Pendo, session replays. A very cool way to visualize user sessions.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Points to session replay as a concrete method for diagnosing UX issues beyond aggregate metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Building analytics from scratch can be time-consuming, expensive, and a really challenging process.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A cautionary observation that can influence build-vs-buy decisions for embedded analytics.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I've seen that a lot of companies, and this was definitely true to Airbnb, where the product team looks down a little bit on the ops team where they're like, "oh, we're doing things that are going to scale to millions of users. We're doing these things that are going to apply to everyone."
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A contrarian cultural insight about product vs. ops dynamics that can help teams collaborate more effectively.

quotes.topic_title: Product vs ops tension and mutual respect
quotes.text: Uber always had this mentality and OpenDoor does too of like a twin turbine jet plane where you can fly the plane on one engine for a little bit if you need to, but it's operating most efficiently and effectively if both are working together, and I think that's really true, right?
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for treating product and ops as complementary “twin engines” rather than competing functions.

quotes.topic_title: Product vs ops tension and mutual respect
quotes.text: The reality is operations teams, local teams, can iterate faster, can scale talking to customers really much more efficiently, have great qualitative insights, and so if it's seen more as a harmony instead of a competition, I think that's really, really helpful
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Actionable reframing: ops can be the faster iteration and customer-insight engine, so teams should optimize for collaboration.

quotes.topic_title: Product vs ops tension and mutual respect
quotes.text: how do we get the insights that are happening day in and day out in the field, on the ground, whatever that may be, and help us build better products because of that, right?
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A practical prompt for building feedback loops that turn frontline learnings into product improvements.

quotes.topic_title: Product vs ops tension and mutual respect
quotes.text: Like a PM sitting in San Francisco can't be in Opendoor's case 50 markets, walking houses every single day in Uber's case, whatever, a thousand cities understanding the nuances of safety in South America and it's just not possible, but what you can do is foster a really good relationship and a really good feedback loop of how people who do deeply understand those things can help give insights.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A concrete scaling example that argues for structured field-to-product feedback loops because PMs can’t directly experience every market nuance.

quotes.topic_title: Origin and purpose of product operations
quotes.text: At Uber it was basically this notion that we had centralized, this was later in my career at Uber, but we had a centralized product team building stuff mostly in San Francisco, not strictly through the Ross, but at this point around the world, but mostly in San Francisco and then we had a very globally distributed operations team, and there was a bidirectional feedback loop that wasn't super strong and that feedback loop was basically when the EPD teams in San Francisco built new features, how do we effectively put it in global markets and then how do we effectively get input from global markets to better build features.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Defines product ops as strengthening a weak bidirectional feedback loop between centralized product builders and distributed market operators.

quotes.topic_title: Origin and purpose of product operations
quotes.text: And so one solution to that problem, our solution at the time was to start up a new function called product operations who had accountability and reported into operations but physically sat with and operated much like a member of the product team to help solve that.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Offers an org-design pattern: product ops reports into ops but embeds with product to bridge execution and market feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Origin and purpose of product operations
quotes.text: I don't think so because at the time, I believe Google had a function, I can't remember what Google called it was something slightly different, but I met with a few folks who had been in similar type roles at Google and a couple other places, so I don't take credit for certainly for inventing IT and other people have actually dabbled in this model at Uber before me there was just a formalization of it and our actual building out of the organization, et cetera.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Highlights that “product ops” often emerges by formalizing and scaling an existing informal bridging role rather than inventing something new.

quotes.topic_title: Early Uber surge pricing: humans in loop
quotes.text: one thing that is true is that surge pricing for actually quite sometimes all of 2012, certainly 2013 probably, I don't know when we necessarily switched, was very much a human in the loop system or a very manual system where GMs in every city would control basically the parameters in which surge would operate
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Highlights a pragmatic “human-in-the-loop” operating model for launching high-stakes algorithms before full automation is ready.

quotes.topic_title: Early Uber surge pricing: humans in loop
quotes.text: Monday through Friday, there would be no search, it couldn't flip on, and then Friday nights and Saturday nights it would flip on from whatever you set, 7:00 PM to 3:00 AM and the cap was X, whatever the cap was.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Concrete example of using time windows and caps as guardrails to safely deploy dynamic pricing.

quotes.topic_title: Early Uber surge pricing: humans in loop
quotes.text: GMs controlled whether it was on or off and what geographies were surging.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Emphasizes decentralizing control to local operators as a lever for quality and risk management in early-stage systems.

quotes.topic_title: Early Uber surge pricing: humans in loop
quotes.text: this is a fairly new concept and it's powerful and dangerous and so let's make sure we understand what's happening.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A memorable risk framing for rolling out impactful product mechanics: prioritize understanding and control early.

quotes.topic_title: Early Uber surge pricing: humans in loop
quotes.text: this belief that local city teams know their cities best and so you might know that an event is happening, a baseball game gets out and it's like, oh, I know that this baseball game's going to get out at 10:00 PM so I'm going to set surge at 9:45 and the algorithm may not be able to pick that up.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Illustrates how local, human context can outperform algorithms on sparse or hard-to-model signals (events, timing, geography).

quotes.topic_title: Scaling war stories: UberX name and China launch
quotes.text: So what do you put in some placeholder? X. So UberX and then the company was moving quickly enough, the product got the green light, it launched, and here we are, I don't know, 12 years later, 11 years later, whatever it is and UberX is the name that stuck.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A concrete example of how fast execution can cement “temporary” decisions into long-term product reality—useful for naming, branding, and shipping tradeoffs.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling war stories: UberX name and China launch
quotes.text: Exactly. It's too expensive to change and rebrand at this point.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Highlights path dependence: early choices create switching costs that can make later “fixes” impractical, informing how teams treat placeholders and defaults.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling war stories: UberX name and China launch
quotes.text: I remember I slept about 30 minutes that night between 2:00 and 3:00 AM being like, okay, well, we have to go live at 6:00 AM I think there was some press around it.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A vivid scaling war story about launch pressure and external commitments (press) driving all-hands execution under extreme constraints.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling war stories: UberX name and China launch
quotes.text: I have to imagine they were not that good, but in my mind it was the best meal I've ever had in my life.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Captures the counterintuitive way high-stress, sleep-deprived moments can become the most memorable and bonding experiences for teams.

quotes.topic_title: Scaling war stories: UberX name and China launch
quotes.text: And we took those few months and then came out the other side and had virtualized the whole process.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A practical crisis-response pattern: pause core operations when assumptions break, then use the downtime to redesign the workflow end-to-end.

quotes.topic_title: Opendoor’s COVID pivot to virtual processes
quotes.text: And you look at the real estate data coming out of China at the time and it looked like coming to a standstill, and so we actually turned off the core business and we stopped buying homes for a few months.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Highlights a decisive, data-informed move to pause the core business rather than push through uncertainty.

quotes.topic_title: Opendoor’s COVID pivot to virtual processes
quotes.text: hey, we can't go in and we don't know if anyone's going to be buying any homes, and so what do we do?
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Captures the practical decision point teams face when core assumptions break and demand becomes unknowable.

quotes.topic_title: Opendoor’s COVID pivot to virtual processes
quotes.text: And we took those few months and then came out the other side and had virtualized the whole process.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Shows how to use an operational shutdown window to redesign workflows and remove physical dependencies.

quotes.topic_title: Opendoor’s COVID pivot to virtual processes
quotes.text: Then it was pretty stressful, right, because looking at a business that relies on going into people's homes and suddenly you can't do that anymore, what do you do?
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Illustrates the existential risk of single-point operational dependencies and the need for contingency planning.

quotes.topic_title: What Opendoor does: simple home selling
quotes.text: So we're a digital platform to buy and sell real estate.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A crisp positioning statement that clarifies the product category and scope in one line.

quotes.topic_title: What Opendoor does: simple home selling
quotes.text: The core product today is a seller focused product where people can go online, enter some information about their home, and we'll make an all cash offer to be able to sell simplicity and certainty.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Defines the core workflow and value proposition (cash offer) as a mechanism to deliver “simplicity and certainty.”

quotes.topic_title: What Opendoor does: simple home selling
quotes.text: So the product really works for people who want something that is certain and simple and easy.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Highlights a clear target segment based on desired outcome rather than demographics.

quotes.topic_title: What Opendoor does: simple home selling
quotes.text: I don't know if you've ever sold a home, but it can be a very, very, very successful difficult process with showings and open houses and how to price it and will it sell and all of that stuff.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Names the concrete pain points the product removes, useful for framing problem statements and messaging.

quotes.topic_title: What Opendoor does: simple home selling
quotes.text: You picked your closing date, you move out when you want. Yeah, there's no hassle.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A memorable articulation of flexibility and reduced friction as key product benefits.

quotes.topic_title: Making product and ops work together
quotes.text: The first one we touched on, which is a, there's just got to be mutual respect. Both functions have their time and their place and their skillsets, and you just don't build big businesses of this type without respecting the fact that that both need to exist.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A foundational operating principle for aligning product/engineering with ops in ops-heavy businesses.

quotes.topic_title: Making product and ops work together
quotes.text: The second, particularly on the product and engineering side, is really understanding where and how the technology leverage comes from the business and then being really focused on making sure generally, especially in the earlier days, you are more limited on the technical resourcing side than you might be on the operational resourcing side.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A resource-allocation lens: assume engineering is the bottleneck early and invest only where tech creates outsized leverage.

quotes.topic_title: Making product and ops work together
quotes.text: And so how do you be really focused on where to invest your time, effort, and energy technically, which is why most of the engineering effort for Uber was on the dispatching system and the pricing system.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A concrete example of concentrating engineering on the highest-leverage systems rather than spreading effort across many improvements.

quotes.topic_title: Making product and ops work together
quotes.text: And so I think the second one is being really intentional about where those techs are and then being really forthcoming and saying, hey, that means all these other places where yes, it can make things easier, more efficient, et cetera, et cetera. We are okay not investing in right now, and that needs to be an explicit decision and very transparent.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A practical methodology: explicitly and transparently decide what you won’t build yet to avoid misalignment and thrash.

quotes.topic_title: Making product and ops work together
quotes.text: But then the last bit I would say is a deep understanding that the real world has entropy and it's hard and it's messy for us at Opendoor, we go into homes, someone may not be home, scheduling may be off, at Uber the driver may cancel the radio GPS. All these things happen, right? Computers are deterministic, but humans aren't, right? And so building products that have a little bit more flex or a little bit more fail safes in case those things happen becomes a little bit more of a paramount.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A mental model for ops-heavy products: design for non-deterministic human behavior with flexibility and fail-safes.

quotes.topic_title: From doing things manually to scaling with tech
quotes.text: So, you say, okay, we have gone from the iteration stage to the scale stage and technology is uniquely good at scaling.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for recognizing the inflection point where ops/process tweaks stop working and software becomes the right lever.

quotes.topic_title: From doing things manually to scaling with tech
quotes.text: And we said, okay, let's make a video. Instead of giving verbally the same presentation, let's just make an onboarding video and that was the next set of scale, but now suddenly we have a different problem, which is okay, you have to validate all of these credentials.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A concrete example of scaling in layers—standardize delivery first, then tackle the next bottleneck that emerges (verification).

quotes.topic_title: From doing things manually to scaling with tech
quotes.text: One, you've scaled your system, and two, you've just created a ton of time for what at the time was probably dozens if not hundreds of people running these onboarding sessions all over the country, the world at the time to do other stuff.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Highlights the dual payoff of automation: throughput increases while freeing operational capacity to redeploy to higher-leverage problems.

quotes.topic_title: From doing things manually to scaling with tech
quotes.text: The way I like to think about this is do things that don't scale and then scale the things that you're doing.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable operating principle for early-stage execution: start manual to learn, then systematize what works.

quotes.topic_title: From doing things manually to scaling with tech
quotes.text: He talked about that operations is usually, and it's a hot take, that operations is a sign of inefficiency and over time your job is to squeeze that away and make it product software as much as possible.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive lens that reframes ops work as temporary scaffolding to be progressively replaced by product and automation.

quotes.topic_title: How to run effective product reviews
quotes.text: In terms of things I've learned, I think being really intentional about what the goals are, I think it's okay to say that there are two goals, a goal of accountability and inform to an audience.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Defines a clear two-goal framing for product reviews so teams align on purpose and expectations.

quotes.topic_title: How to run effective product reviews
quotes.text: But also most importantly, I think this is the primary goal is to help make the product better, to help the teams think through a problem and to have that, again, back to our earliest conversation, be a very intellectual conversation about the work and how to make the product better and not super scary.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Reorients product reviews away from status/performance theater toward collaborative problem-solving.

quotes.topic_title: How to run effective product reviews
quotes.text: Product reviews hopefully are not feeling like firing squads.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Memorable warning against adversarial review dynamics that reduce learning and quality.

quotes.topic_title: How to run effective product reviews
quotes.text: I am a firm believer in general that the people closest to the problems also have the best context to solve that problem.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A leadership mental model: senior leaders should enable and probe rather than override the team doing the work.

quotes.topic_title: How to run effective product reviews
quotes.text: We, I would say have oscillated over time, but in general, big subscribers of the best conversations happen when they're relatively small, so try and keep it under 10.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Concrete operational guidance on attendee count to keep reviews high-signal and participatory.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: There's a world where your CRM is powerful, easily configured, and deeply intuitive.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Sets a clear product vision for what “good” looks like in CRM software—powerful yet intuitive and configurable.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It syncs with your data sources, easily configures to their unique structures and works for any go-to-market motion from self-serve to sales led.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable checklist of capabilities to look for when choosing or designing a CRM that fits different GTM models.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Attio automatically enriches your contacts, syncs your email and calendar, gives you powerful reports and lets you quickly build Zapier style automations.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Concrete examples of workflow automation and data integration features that reduce manual ops work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The next era of companies deserves more than an inflexible one size fits all CRM.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Contrarian positioning against traditional CRMs, emphasizing flexibility as a competitive advantage.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I'd love to hear just how you actually apply it at Opendoor, what you've learned about how to apply jobs to be done effectively.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a practitioner-focused lens on Jobs To Be Done—implementation details and lessons learned, not theory.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs-to-be-done at Opendoor in practice
quotes.text: Yeah. I think like all frameworks, the right answer is to pick your set of frameworks, have more tools in your toolbox, and then actually understand when and how to apply them. So we try to avoid being a hammer and everything's a nail. We try to for course the framework if it's not working.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A practical meta-framework for using JTBD (and any framework) without becoming dogmatic or forcing-fit solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs-to-be-done at Opendoor in practice
quotes.text: Most people at Opendoor, we don't have homes to sell every week or every month, nor do we buy homes every week or every month. On average in the US is something people do once every seven years.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A concrete data point explaining why empathy and structured customer thinking matter more in infrequent, high-stakes journeys.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs-to-be-done at Opendoor in practice
quotes.text: I would say we're medium rigorous on template standardization or adherence. So we do have a template, the standard product review template talks about jobs to be done and has a section for what is the problem statement and what are the jobs to be done.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Shows an implementable mechanism: embedding JTBD into product review docs without over-enforcing process.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs-to-be-done at Opendoor in practice
quotes.text: Recognizing that correctly implementing a framework, any framework, but if you don't in particular, we can talk about takes a little bit of time and getting used to and understanding. And so I don't think you can just like, okay, we're going to make the template and then that makes the content better. That just takes people's content and they wedge it into the template. It's actually the cultural internalization of like, hey, this might be phrased as the job to be done, but is this actually the job to be done?
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Counterintuitive lesson: templates don’t create better thinking—culture and debate do.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs-to-be-done at Opendoor in practice
quotes.text: Or you might say, hey, the job to be done is maybe an early day version would be the job to be done is to get an offer from Opendoor. And it's like, well kind of, but the broader job to be done might be price discovery for the customer.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A sharp example of reframing from company-centric goals to the customer’s underlying job, enabling better product decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation with low volume and intuition
quotes.text: don't just force yourself into A/B testing without running the power analysis and say like, hey, are we going to get results? What is the size that will detect and what is the runtime of that experiment?
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A practical guardrail: validate feasibility (MDE + runtime) before committing to an A/B test in low-volume areas.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation with low volume and intuition
quotes.text: there certain experiments that are important enough and it's hard to triangulate signal in any other way that you may say a six-month runtime is an acceptable outcome and we are going to start it in June and we will be smarter for it for 2025 planning and we're going to set it and forget it and we're grateful we did, and that's okay.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A counterintuitive planning mindset: long-running experiments can be worth it if they unlock strategic clarity.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation with low volume and intuition
quotes.text: if there are parts of your funnel or flow that are low end and you can't run a canonical A/B test, how might you otherwise increase your conviction in the solution that you're building?
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A reusable framework question for choosing alternative validation methods when standard experimentation isn’t possible.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation with low volume and intuition
quotes.text: You may be able to use observational data, you review with diff and diff, you may be able to look at sister cities or twin cities. You may be able to segment by geo, you may be able to reduce your power and say, hey, we're going to run at 80% confidence for all of our experiments instead of this traditional 95% because that's a worthy trade-off. And if we're wrong one more time out of 10, that's okay.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A concrete menu of lower-rigor but high-leverage techniques to build conviction under sample-size constraints.

quotes.topic_title: Experimentation with low volume and intuition
quotes.text: if you're not going to get significance, if there's no other techniques at your disposal, then sometimes you just got to trust your intuition and ship it. And if that's what you believe, then that's what you believed and you shouldn't spend time trying to get false precision.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: A decision rule: avoid performative analytics and ship with judgment when significance is unattainable.

quotes.topic_title: Zillow competition and partnership setup
quotes.text: I think when you think about it, they have tremendous amount of reach and audience and all these online platforms have tremendous reach and audience.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Highlights a practical partnering lens: platforms with massive demand capture can complement companies that execute the transaction.

quotes.topic_title: Zillow competition and partnership setup
quotes.text: And we happen to have a fairly unique selling solution.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Emphasizes differentiation as the basis for partnership leverage—bring a capability the platform doesn’t already have.

quotes.topic_title: Zillow competition and partnership setup
quotes.text: And so there's a nice, not to use a business school word, but there's a nice synergy so to speak, between a high intended audience who's doing a lot of browsing and searching and discovery and starting their process on one of these online platforms and what we offer, which is transaction services that allow people to actually move particularly on the seller side.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Provides a clear mental model for marketplace partnerships: pair top-of-funnel intent (discovery) with bottom-of-funnel execution (transactions).

quotes.topic_title: Zillow competition and partnership setup
quotes.text: And so there's just a pretty nice symbiotic relationship there with the Zillow's and the regimens of the world.
quotes.speaker: Brian Tolkin
quotes.context: Frames “frenemies” turning into partners as a repeatable pattern when capabilities are complementary rather than substitutable.
